definitions: illegally distilled or smuggled alcohol produced without government authorization
bright light reflected from the moon that illuminates the night
foolish or exaggerated talk that lacks substance or truth
examples: They made moonshine in hidden stills during Prohibition
The sheriff discovered moonshine barrels in the abandoned barn
The garden looked magical in the bright moonshine last night
We could see clearly by the moonshine without using flashlights
Don't believe his stories about treasure maps; it's all moonshine
Politicians promised lower taxes, but voters knew it was moonshine

definitions: translucent feldspar gemstone with pearly luster that exhibits internal light reflection
examples: Her engagement ring featured a beautiful moonstone surrounded by diamonds
The moonstone exhibited a blue sheen when moved under light

definitions: open uncultivated upland with acidic soil covered mainly with heather
secure a boat with cables or ropes to fixed point
examples: The purple heather bloomed across the Scottish moor in autumn
They searched the windswept moor for the missing hikers
We need to moor the yacht before the storm arrives
The captain decided to moor alongside the harbor wall

definitions: ropes, cables, or chains used to secure a boat or ship
place where boats or ships are tied up or anchored
examples: The storm damaged several mooring lines at the marina
We checked all mooring equipment before leaving the harbor
The yacht club has mooring facilities for fifty boats
They reserved a mooring near the restaurant for dinner

definitions: extensive area of moor typically covered with heather and rough grass
examples: The moorland stretched for miles under the gray Yorkshire sky
Wildlife thrives in the protected moorland despite harsh conditions

definitions: largest member of deer family with broad flat antlers found in northern regions
examples: A massive moose crossed the highway in front of our car
The bull moose stood seven feet tall at the shoulder

definitions: cleaning implement with absorbent strings or sponge attached to handle
thick untidy mass of hair on someone's head
examples: She used a wet mop to clean the kitchen floor
The janitor wrung out the mop before continuing
His curly mop of hair needed a serious haircut
The toddler had an adorable mop of blonde curls

definitions: low-powered motorcycle with pedals and small engine typically under fifty cubic centimeters
examples: Teenagers ride mopeds around town because they don't require licenses
Her vintage moped gets excellent gas mileage for commuting

definitions: action of cleaning floors with a mop and water or cleaning solution
examples: The weekly mopping keeps the restaurant floors spotlessly clean
After mopping the bathroom, she disinfected all the surfaces

definitions: principle concerning right and wrong behavior that guides personal conduct
practical lesson that can be derived from a story or experience
examples: His strong moral code prevented him from accepting bribes
Society debates moral questions about genetic engineering constantly
The moral of the fable teaches children about honesty
Every fairy tale has a moral about good triumphing over evil

definitions: confidence, enthusiasm, and discipline of a person or group at a particular time
examples: Company morale improved after the successful product launch announcement
The coach's speech boosted team morale before the championship game

definitions: principles concerning the distinction between right and wrong or good and bad
extent to which an action conforms to accepted standards of right conduct
examples: Different cultures have varying views on morality and social behavior
Philosophers have debated questions of morality for thousands of years
The morality of genetic modification remains a controversial scientific topic
Politicians questioned the morality of the proposed tax changes

definitions: act of commenting on moral issues in a self-righteous or tedious way
examples: His constant moralizing about workplace behavior annoyed his colleagues
The novel suffered from excessive moralizing instead of storytelling

definitions: temporary suspension of an activity or law agreed to by authorities or participants
examples: The government declared a moratorium on offshore drilling after the spill
Banks agreed to a moratorium on foreclosures during the economic crisis

definitions: rate of disease or proportion of sickness in a specific population
abnormal interest in disturbing subjects like death or disease
examples: Researchers tracked morbidity rates across different age groups annually
Smoking significantly increases morbidity from respiratory and cardiovascular diseases
His morbidity showed in his collection of crime scene photographs
The film's morbidity made it unsuitable for younger audiences

definitions: place where dead bodies are kept for identification or autopsy before burial
examples: The detective examined evidence at the city morgue downtown
Bodies from the accident were transported to the hospital morgue

definitions: period of time from sunrise to noon or midnight to noon
examples: She drinks coffee every morning before starting work
The morning mist cleared as the sun rose higher

definitions: informal offensive term for a person considered extremely foolish or stupid
examples: He felt like a moron after locking his keys in the car
Don't be a moron; wear your seatbelt when driving

definitions: powerful opioid drug derived from opium used medically for severe pain relief
examples: The doctor prescribed morphine after the patient's major surgery
Morphine effectively controls pain but carries addiction risks

definitions: scientific study of the form and structure of organisms or things
study of the forms and formation of words in language
examples: Plant morphology examines leaf shapes and root structures systematically
The morphology of cancer cells differs from normal healthy cells
English morphology includes prefixes, suffixes, and compound word formation
Students analyzed the morphology of irregular verbs in class

definitions: human being subject to death as opposed to divine or immortal beings
causing or liable to cause death; extremely serious or severe
examples: Every mortal faces the inevitability of death eventually
Greek myths tell of gods interacting with mere mortals
The warrior received a mortal wound in the battle
They were mortal enemies who fought for decades

definitions: number of deaths in a population during a specific time period
state of being subject to death; human condition of eventual death
examples: Infant mortality rates have decreased significantly with modern medicine
The pandemic increased mortality among elderly populations worldwide
Philosophers contemplate human mortality and the meaning of life
The accident reminded him of his own mortality

definitions: mixture of cement, sand, and water used to bind bricks or stones
bowl-shaped container in which substances are crushed with a pestle
short smoothbore gun for firing shells at high angles
examples: The mason mixed mortar to repair the brick wall
Ancient mortar still holds the castle stones together firmly
She ground spices in a marble mortar and pestle
The pharmacist used a mortar to prepare the compound
Enemy forces fired mortar shells at the military base
The mortar team provided indirect fire support

definitions: legal agreement by which a bank lends money for property purchase with property as security
examples: They took out a thirty-year mortgage to buy their first home
Rising interest rates made mortgage payments more expensive monthly

definitions: feeling of severe embarrassment, shame, or wounded pride from humiliation
death and decay of body tissue due to injury or lack of blood supply
examples: She felt deep mortification when she tripped on stage
His mortification was obvious when his mistake was publicly announced
Gangrene involves mortification of tissue requiring immediate medical attention
The doctor examined the wound for signs of mortification

definitions: building or room where dead bodies are kept before burial or cremation
examples: The family made funeral arrangements at the local mortuary
The mortuary prepared the body for the viewing ceremony

definitions: picture or pattern produced by arranging small colored pieces of stone, tile, or glass
combination of diverse elements forming a coherent whole or pattern
examples: Ancient Roman mosaics still decorate the villa floors beautifully
The artist created a stunning mosaic using recycled glass pieces
The city represents a cultural mosaic of different ethnic communities
Satellite images revealed a mosaic of agricultural fields below

definitions: building used for public worship by Muslims, typically featuring a minaret
examples: The mosque's minaret calls believers to prayer five times daily
Worshippers removed their shoes before entering the mosque

definitions: small flying insect that feeds on blood and can transmit diseases
examples: Mosquitoes spread malaria in many tropical regions worldwide
The camping trip was ruined by swarms of hungry mosquitoes

definitions: hotel designed for motorists with rooms accessible from parking area
examples: They stayed at a motel during their cross-country road trip
The motel offered convenient parking directly outside each room

definitions: insect similar to butterfly that is typically nocturnal and attracted to light
examples: Moths circled the porch light throughout the summer evening
The wool sweater had holes where moths had eaten it

definitions: woman in relation to her child or children through birth or adoption
source or origin from which something comes or is derived
examples: His mother taught him to read before he started school
The mother comforted her crying baby with gentle rocking
Necessity is the mother of invention, as the saying goes
The mother ship launched several smaller reconnaissance vessels

definitions: state or experience of being a mother and having maternal responsibilities
examples: Motherhood changed her priorities and perspective on life completely
She balanced motherhood with her demanding career successfully

definitions: one's native country or homeland, especially when regarded with patriotic feelings
examples: Immigrants often maintain strong connections to their motherland
Soldiers fought bravely to defend their motherland from invasion

definitions: distinctive feature or dominant idea in artistic or literary composition
decorative design or pattern used as a repeated element
examples: The butterfly motif appears throughout the novel symbolizing transformation
Musical motifs help unify the symphony's four movements
The wallpaper featured a floral motif in blue and gold
Celtic motifs decorated the ancient manuscript's margins

definitions: action or process of moving or changing position in space
formal proposal put to a legislature or committee for decision
examples: The security camera captured the thief's motion across the room
Newton's laws describe the motion of objects in space
The board voted on a motion to increase membership fees
She seconded the motion to adjourn the meeting early

definitions: act of providing someone with a reason or incentive for doing something
examples: Motivating teenagers requires understanding their interests and goals
The coach excelled at motivating players during difficult games

definitions: general desire or willingness to do something; enthusiasm and determination
reason or reasons for acting or behaving in a particular way
examples: Her motivation to succeed came from wanting to help her family
The team lacked motivation after losing several games consecutively
Police investigated the suspect's motivation for committing the crime
Understanding customer motivation helps improve marketing strategies

definitions: person who encourages or inspires others to take action or improve
factor or incentive that drives someone to act in a certain way
examples: The personal trainer was an excellent motivator for her clients
Great teachers are natural motivators who inspire student learning
Money isn't the only motivator for employee performance
Fear can be a powerful motivator for behavioral change

definitions: reason for doing something, especially one that is hidden or not obvious
examples: Detectives searched for a motive behind the mysterious disappearance
His true motive for helping was personal gain, not kindness

definitions: machine that supplies motive power for a vehicle or other device
relating to muscular movement or the nerves activating muscles
examples: The electric motor powers the conveyor belt in the factory
She replaced the motor in her washing machine herself
Children develop motor skills through play and physical activity
The stroke affected his motor functions on the left side

definitions: lightweight motorcycle, especially one with a small engine
examples: He commutes to work on his motorbike to avoid traffic
The delivery service uses motorbikes for faster urban deliveries

definitions: boat powered by an internal combustion or electric motor
examples: They rented a motorboat to explore the lake's hidden coves
The motorboat sped across the calm water leaving a wake

definitions: procession of motor vehicles, typically carrying important people
examples: The presidential motorcade traveled through downtown with heavy security
A motorcade of limousines arrived at the diplomatic summit

definitions: two-wheeled motor vehicle with an engine larger than a moped
examples: She bought a motorcycle for weekend trips through the mountains
Motorcycle riders must wear helmets according to state law

definitions: activity or sport of riding motorcycles either recreationally or competitively
examples: Motorcycling through the countryside offers scenic views and freedom
Professional motorcycling requires exceptional skill and physical fitness

definitions: person who rides a motorcycle, especially as a regular activity
examples: The motorcyclist wore protective leather gear for safety
Several motorcyclists formed a club for weekend group rides

definitions: activity of driving a motor vehicle or traveling by car
examples: Sunday motoring through the countryside became their favorite pastime
Motoring magazines review the latest car models and technology

definitions: person who drives a car, especially as regular transportation
examples: Motorists faced long delays due to highway construction work
The stranded motorist waited for roadside assistance to arrive

definitions: wide road designed for fast traffic with controlled access and multiple lanes
examples: The motorway connects major cities across the entire country
Speed limits on motorways are higher than regular roads
